title: CTRL0000050986 - Transcribed Interview of Carla Krzywicki, (March 2, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Zoom, commencing at 3:01 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
So we are on the record at 3:01 p.m., and, as you just heard, this is
This is the transcribed interview of Ms. Carla -- and, actually,
can you pronounce your last name for me?
I want to make sure I get it right.
This is a transcribed interview of Ms. Carla Krzywicki, conducted by the House
Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol
At this time, I'd ask the witness to please state your full name and then spell your
Carla Jean Krzywicki, and my last name is spelled K-r-z-y-w-i-c-k-i.
And this will be a staff-led interview.
some point and ask a question.
And they may also choose to ask questions.
Members of the committee may join at
I don't really expect that to happen, but it's possible.
Speaking, as I introduced myself earlier, i s - investigative counsel with
And then also in the room today is
And then, at this time, counsel, could you please state your name for the record?
So, Carla, there is an official reporter transcribing this interview.
until I finish my questions before you start your response, and then I'll also try to wait
until you finish your answer before I start my next question.
to record two people talking at the same time, so we'll try to be nice to Nicole and Katy
And then, also, relatedly, they can't record nonverbal responses, so just make sure
you use "yes" or "no" instead of, like, a head shake or a nod.
And then we ask that you provide complete answers just to the best of your
If the question's not clear, ask me to rephrase it, or you could ask for
And then, if you don't know the answer, that's totally fine.
And then I want to just go through kind of a few housekeeping
matters and, sort of, ground rules.
So, first, I just want to make sure you understand that this is a voluntary interview.
If at any time you'd like to stop speaking with us, that's your choice.
Similarly, at any point if you need to discuss something with your attorney in
private, just let us know, and we'll be happy to take a break that so you can have that
And then, second, this interview is not under oath, but because you're speaking to
congressional investigators, you are obligated under Federal law to tell the truth, the
same as if you were speaking with FBI or DOJ.
And so it's deliberately unlawful to provide false information to Congress for this
Providing false information could result in criminal penalties for false
Third, you are not obligated to keep the fact of this interview or what we discuss
that includes a prosecutor or your judge, or you could tell nobody at all.
You're free to tell whomever you may wish that you met with us, and then
And then, fourth, I just want to make sure that you understand that the select
committee is separate and independent from the Department of Justice.
involvement with prosecutions, and the DOJ is really not a partner of the select
The select committee's not a party to your criminal case and is not agreeing to
submit anything on your behalf to the judge, nor can we make any representation
whether, if you tell the judge that you met us, that the judge will be more favorable to
And then, fifth, we've agreed with your attorney that we're not going to share
what you've said with the DOJ prior to your sentencing, but there are a couple possible
exceptions that we should note just quickly.
If you told us about evidence of a crime that we thought law enforcement was
unaware of, then that might trigger an obligation to share that information with DOJ.
Or if we have reason to believe that you told us something that wasn't true during this
So as long as we stay away from those things, then we're good today.
Also, I'll just add that, if you tell the judge that you met us, please understand that
that might prompt questions from the judge about what you said and whether it's
consistent with your prior statements and acceptance of responsibility, and if the judge
starts asking questions, we may be asked to respond and divulge what you said during
So just a final, kind of, related note.
And then just as we go through today, I mean, hopefully we can get you out of
here pretty quickly, but we might go for an hour or two.
point, feel free to just let me know, and we can take that kind of break.
you need to talk to Ms. Shaner for anything, just let us know.
So if you need a break at some
Then let's just start with some, sort of, background questions.
I lived there for about 19 years.
And how long have you lived there?
And so that's all of your life, pretty much?
And then I moved to Bozrah, Connecticut, as of last
And then could you just give us a quick run-through of your educational
I went to school in Canterbury for elementary and middle school.
And then for high school I went to Norwich Technical High School, where I took electrical.
And then I graduated in 2019, and I started college in 2019.
I go to Three Rivers Community College, and I haven't gotten a degree yet.
Like, a side job or anything like that.
And, then, where are you in college?
Do you do any other work other than just schoolwork?
I'm employed by Wendy's as a manager, and that's the only thing I do.
Let's kind of go back to 2020, a little bit before the general election, in the,
you describe your level of political engagement at that time?
And I just want to know in general, how would
I would say I didn't know enough about politics to really pick a side, I would
I wasn't very, like, educated enough to know enough about it.
And was that sort of the same throughout Trump's Presidency the
Would you say you were politically active or just kind of how you
I personally would say that I just wasn't educated enough.
conservative household, so I was around that, so I would say I wouldn't really know any
If I were to say, at the time, I thought more conservative.
up and got into, like, the real world, I realized I'm not really -- I was not -- I did not know
And then I'll note Ms. Shaner corrected me for the record.
At the time, I was still a teenager, so, like, just social media in general, like,
Let's talk a little bit about, kind of, at that time, news sources that you
Did you watch any news on TV?
What would you say your main, sort of, sources of news were at that
Did you and your mom share a lot of information about news or
I was raised in her household, so she -- she would watch the news.
if I did see any news.
It would be, like, at dinnertime.
And it was usually the local news.
So that's, in my opinion, not necessarily the best at two sides.
sometimes we would talk about, like, what was going on in the world, not necessarily,
like, here in the United States.
And how about using social media to get news?
Did you do that around that
Around -- I used Facebook but not necessarily for, like, news purposes.
I'm going to run through just a couple kinds of sources, common sources of news
through social media that people use, and let me know if you used any of these or if you,
kind of, sought out news about, you know, the election in particular or news in general
So we talked about Facebook already.
I do have Twitter, but I don't use it for news.
I use TikTok, but it's not -- it's definitely not for news.
The algorithm isn't giving you news?
So, then, it sounds like in general -- and, sorry, not to belabor the point,
but -- there wasn't really any particular source of news that you were looking to, and you
weren't really, kind of, like, on a day-to-day basis actively seeking out news information.
Did you follow President Trump on any social media at that time?
I think I might've followed him on Facebook in high school, but, I mean --
I'm sorry, what was that last one?
that stand out in your mind?
And then do you remember any, kind of, thoughts you had about his
Sorry, the audio just cut out for a second.
Any particular instances of anything that he said
Just that it seemed very silly, some of the things that he would
How about right around the general election?
President Trump said that sticks out in your mind that he might've said about the
We can move on from, kind of, the -- oh, -
posting things on Facebook related to politics at that time?
It was just a broad range of
Yes, I had friends that would post about politics.
Did you pay particular attention to it?
Besides what President Trump might've said, were your friends
And then I'll just say, you know, we'll have lots of really specific questions,
obviously, going through this interview today.
And, really, our intention just to kind of is
to understand your mindset going into that day.
None of this is to say that anything was
wrong or right to do, but really we just kind of want your perspective on what brought
So I hope you don't take our, you know, pointed questions to mean anything other
Let's talk a little bit about, kind of, what you thought of the general
election -- so that's the election in November -- and, kind of, how your feelings were
Did you think that the election was stolen from former President
Did friends or family that you were speaking to have
I can't speak for her, but possibly.
Or, did you guys have conversations where she said that she thought the
We didn't really talk politics because sometimes we didn't really see
So it wasn't something -- like, a conversation happened and ended very
And then how about your mom?
Were there any sorts of rallies or, kind of, political events that you
What were those conversations like with your mom?
mentioned earlier that you sort of grew up sometimes watching FOX News.
tone of them shift around the 2020 election?
As I grew up, I realized, like, some of the things -- like, I
don't agree with, like, a lot of older generations', like, that kind of mindset, if you
understand, like, what I'm getting at.
things like that where they're more conservative, I'm not.
Like, just, like, women's rights, gay rights kind of
So it kind of -- like, if I, like, say, like, women's right to choose, like, abortion and
stuff like that, like, my mom definitely is pro-life, where I'm, like, pro-choice.
conversations like that, it just wasn't worth getting into an argument.
And did the 2020 election, did you feel that heated that sort
I guess I'll just ask more broadly -- I know that's -- about specific rallies or
But did your political perspective change at all or did you kind of have a

election, or kind of the same as before?
So I know we talked about your political activity, kind of, before the general
I would say they somewhat changed just, like, growing up in general,
because I was really young when that had happened -- still am.
up and realizing a lot more things, I would say they had changed --
I think you cut out a little bit at the end.
You said "I would say," and then I
I would say, yes, they have changed slightly.
And do you mean after January 6th?
Were you feeling differently after the election?
I would say I would lean more left now.
I was kind of focusing on the time between November to
And how did your, kind of, politics change?
Let's just talk about, kind of, how you ended up in D.C. and what

Can you just tell me generally -- you know, it sounds like you weren't too

what brought you to D.C. on that day?
So my mom was supposed to go to see the President speak with her older
going to take, I believe it was a bus trip from Norwich, Connecticut, down to D.C.
her friends didn't want to sit on the bus trip for that long, being older, so she had asked
And her friend are even older.
if I would go with her, and I said, "Well, we could watch it on TV," kind of thing.
really wanted to go see, since it would be the last time he would speak as President.
And so she had asked me
So I ended up going with her to make sure she would be okay.
So I had said, well, I hope she's not gonna go alone.
kind -- she's been to rallies before.
And she'll , so I didn't want that to
So I pretty much just went with her to make sure she'd be okay.
And what did you think January 6th was going to be like when you were, kind

What did you think the events were going to be
I thought they'd be, like, just him speaking and it'd be like his typical rallies.
Like, when I was in high school, my mom had taken me to when he speaks at stadiums
and cheering him on, listening to him speak.
And it's just, like, the atmosphere is all these people getting along
And I thought it would be like that.
So you said you went to rallies of President
When I was in high school.
But you said you weren't very politically engaged?
I was kind of just, like, brought along.
Did you think you supported President Trump at that time?
So when you were in high school.
And so when was it that -- do you know when it was that your mom decided
to go to the rallies on January 6th?
I want to say 2 weeks, possibly?
Do you know how your mom met the group of people that she was going to go on
And then how far in advance was it that you decided?
the bus with or that you all ended up going on the bus with?
I believe it was on Facebook.

Does the name "Turning Point" ring a bell?
So, in general, you knew it was a Facebook group, but you

Did you guys have to pay for this bus, or

I think my mom had paid someone.
And do you think it was somebody in the Facebook group?
And, then, I take it, since you didn't seem particularly interested in the rallies

So really it was just kind of a trip to go down with your mom

Not leading up to it, no.
And no one posted that they would also be there in D.C.?
For your battery, do you want to take a minute to plug it in, just in case?
I don't know if my phone will stay -- when I get the next warning, I'll plug it

So no one else that you know of in the area was planning to go on
Afterwards, yes, but not leading up to it.
And I didn't want her to go by herself.
And, then, I take it the answer is probably "no," but were you aware

In Norwich, Connecticut, on the lot right by the Walmart and Big V.
And then what was the plan for traveling down?
just -- oh, what day -- sorry -- what day was that, that you picked up the bus?
It was early, early in the morning on January 6th.

I believe it was that we were going to get the bus super-early in the morning,
and then it would, I believe, along the way in Connecticut pick more people up, and then
And then how about when you got on the bus?
kind of, the other people that were on it?
Did you learn anything about the Facebook

A lot of people that were, like, really excited to go.
I couldn't place, like, where I knew her from.
But I didn't really talk to anybody.
This woman that you thought you might know, did you figure out
I think she might have been one of my teachers in school.
So not, like, a celebrity or something.
-- somebody you recognized from around town.
And, then, you didn't know anybody else on the bus other than your mom?
Correct, and then the lady who I think was my teacher.

It was after the President had already spoken.
And, then, why don't you just tell me about that?
I believe we got lost in New York.
And so, then, I take it that caused, sort of, some delay in getting into
So about what time did you end up getting into D.C.?
I don't know any of, like, what anything's called there,
like, a big open field, and there was, like, a statue.
right there in front of us.
Tell me about arriving in D.C.
and then how you got off the bus.
And then I remember walking to,
And then I believe the Capitol was
And then we kind of just made our way up there.

following it live, like, you know, on their phones?

know, did he convince you about his thoughts on the election?
Do you remember just, like, a general feeling?

So you get off the bus.
everybody on the bus doing, or what's the general plan from there?
I remember everybody getting off the bus and then saying that we were
going to meet back at a certain point.
just -- I don't remember, like, watching where everybody went, but they kind of just went.
I think most of the people started walking towards the Capitol.
stayed in, like, the open field area.
And by "open field area," is that, like, The Mall?
I mean when I say "The Mall"?
And, then, I take it that you and your mother joined some of the people

And what did you think about what you saw around this time?
as you were walking from the bus and then just start to walk towards the Capitol, tell me

Did you see a lot of that?
I do remember seeing some people dressed like that, and I

Kind of, but not really, because I thought maybe some people are just very

Was it, like, sort of surprising to see that?
patriotic and wanted to dress like that.
I didn't think of what it could've been used for at
Like, at that time, it seemed more of, like, a costume than it was --
And then tell me a little about, kind of, as you start to walk closer and

then I remember seeing a lot of people waving Trump flags, American flags, a few

And then what did you have with you as you were walking?
I think I just wore a fanny pack
that had -- I wear contacts, so I brought an extra pair -- ChapStick, my license, and I think
How about, were you wearing, like, a Trump T-shirt, or what
I believe I had a Trump sweatshirt on underneath my jacket.
had bought Trump hats there because it was so cold.
And, then, about how long did it take you to walk from wherever the bus was

There were a few people yelling the closer that we got.
Did you hear what they were yelling about?
There was plenty of people chanting, too, that you couldn't
really make out what they were yelling.
I could -- it felt like a lot of people were more angry at this one.

Do you remember why you and your mom decided to follow that crowd
when you got off the bus?
So you didn't know -- you didn't know where you were going?
Did your mom say, "We're going to walk over to the Capitol"?
Can you describe to me where you were when it started to get
It was kind of, like, a mentality, just follow where everybody
But did she seem to -- was there any sense to you -- like, did you
have any sense that you were going to the Capitol?
I just kind of, like, followed her.
crowded like a concert, like you talked about?
I think -- it was on the -- if you were looking at the building, it was on the left
side of where the scaffolding was.
it started to get really crowded?

And then why don't you -- can you walk me through, kind of, what

behind me and seeing so many people.
couldn't, because people, they just wanted to keep pushing forward.
And even if we tried to leave, it was like we
And then I remember, I think people started throwing, like, water bottles.
then there were more police presence on the Capitol.
people having, like, a medical emergency that were brought through the crowd.
And then people started throwing more things.
that would, like, make people disperse.
And then I remember a few
I think it was, like, tear gas being
And that just made people even more upset.
Instead, people got even more upset, started

my mom just kept being, like, shoved forward.
And I remember, like, guards or police officers coming out, dressed in, like -- with
shields and, like, trying to push people back.
And me and my mom were kind of stuck,
not being able to leave, and being pushed forward.

Did you remember your mom ever talking about wanting to go to the
Capitol or march to the Capitol before you guys arrived in D.C.?
And then how about, when you got there on the bus and you see people walking
there, was your mom interested in going to the Capitol, or it just seemed like she was
It seemed like she was just following the crowd.
So, then, you're following the crowd, and it gets more and more crowded,

And you mentioned that tear gas
Were you guys getting exposed to that tear gas?
When it started to get more hectic, we were.

We tried to leave, I believe, two or three times, and there were just so
many people that it was like, you couldn't get through.
I remember, like, the people that were having medical emergencies, like, the

I don't think we really talked.
I just remember her not letting go of, like, my
arm or my hand and just watching everybody else.
Maybe this sounds like a silly question or too simple of a question,
Were you afraid that you were going to get separated from your
I don't think I ever let go of some part of her.
So you continued to get pushed closer and closer towards the front.
then I think you said you started to see police that were in, kind of, like, gear or riot gear

So you felt it was safer to move forward?
It was just so many people pushing.

There were just so -- like, if we were to look

But, you know, even in a giant crowd, sometimes you can push

But, at some point, you see the bike rack.
that you had just seen somebody try to climb up that way and up the scaffolding and then

up scaffolding, you saw somebody get sprayed.
another route that was these bike racks that were stacked up.

You start to climb the bike rack, and

remember going in, like, the scaffolding and up the stairs.

point, if it was either -- we had gone through a door, and the doors had already been

that door area as you were entering?

So, like, if you had happiness and was

Just not really letting go of my mom or letting her out of

Your mom still had her sign, though, right?
was afraid to let it go, because she could see, like, some people just seemed a little too
